parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five studies have assessed the use of acoustically reflective fishing gear materials to reduce marine mammal entanglement.
[Statement 2]: Two of three controlled studies indicated that nets made from materials like iron-oxide or barium sulfate led to fewer harbour porpoise entanglements compared to conventional nets.
[Statement 3]: Another study found that nets made of barium sulfate did not decrease dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 4]: Behavioural studies on acoustically reflective materials have produced mixed findings.
[Statement 5]: One study noted that harbour porpoises used fewer echolocation clicks near barium sulfate nets.
[Statement 6]: Another study found no difference in echolocation activity by harbour porpoises near barium sulfate nets compared to conventional nets.
[Statement 7]: Two studies have evaluated the effect of attaching acoustically reflective objects to fishing gear.
[Statement 8]: One controlled study reported that adding metallic bead chains to nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 9]: Another study found that attaching acrylic beads to fishing gear did not deter sperm whales from preying on fish catches.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does the evidence for using acoustically reflective materials on fishing gear compare to attaching acoustically reflective objects for reducing marine mammal entanglement?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year.
[Statement 2]: Two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year.
[Statement 3]: In a study on Hawaiian monk seals, over a quarter of the seals survived and reproduced after seal pups were reunited with their mothers and at least seven other interventions were implemented.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that evaluated the effectiveness of placing orphaned or abandoned marine and freshwater mammal young with foster parents.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for interventions that directly manage individual mammals to boost threatened populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The use of acoustic deterrent devices has been shown to have several behavioral effects on marine mammals.
[Statement 2]: Common bottlenose dolphins were more likely to avoid a boat when acoustic devices were active.
[Statement 3]: Killer whales maintained a greater distance from a fishing vessel when an acoustic deterrent device was in use.
[Statement 4]: The effect of killer whales maintaining a greater distance from a fishing vessel diminished with repeated exposure to an active acoustic deterrent device.
[Statement 5]: The use of acoustic deterrent devices led to a reduction in surfacing, echolocation rates, and time spent foraging or socializing for Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices on moorings have been found to decrease the activity of harbour porpoises, short-beaked common dolphins, and common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices on moorings have been found to reduce the numbers of grey and harbour seals in the immediate vicinity.
[Statement 8]: Studies have noted a reduction in harbour porpoise echolocation activity in the presence of acoustic deterrent devices.
[Statement 9]: Studies have noted a general decrease in the activity of common bottlenose dolphins in the presence of acoustic deterrent devices.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the potential negative impacts associated with using acoustic deterrent devices for marine mammal conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two of three controlled studies in the North Sea, the Bay of Fundy, and the South Atlantic Ocean found that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials such as iron-oxide or barium sulfate had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
[Statement 2]: One study found that nets made from barium sulfate did not reduce the number of dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in the Fortune Channel found that harbour porpoises used fewer echolocation clicks at nets made from barium sulfate.
[Statement 4]: Another study in the Bay of Fundy found that echolocation activity was similar at both barium sulfate and conventional nets.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective interventions for reducing cetacean bycatch in fishing nets, based on evidence from the Atlantic and North Sea?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 2]: Two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 3]: Most captive-reared Antillean manatees released back into the wild reproduced.
[Statement 4]: Approximately three-quarters of captive-reared and released Antillean manatees were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 5]: Approximately two-thirds of captive-reared and released Florida manatees were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 6]: Some captive-reared and released manatees were known to survive for more than seven years.
[Statement 7]: Three captive-reared West Indian manatee calves either died before or after release.
[Statement 8]: Three captive-reared West Indian manatee calves had to be returned to captivity.
[Statement 9]: Three captive-reared West Indian manatee calves survived in the wild only with supplemental feeding.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for the success of releasing hand-reared or captive-bred manatees back into the wild in the Americas?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the South Atlantic found that using bird exclusion devices with two booms on longlines resulted in fewer seabirds being caught compared to using devices with a single boom.
[Statement 2]: Some studies on marine mammals found that using devices like net sleeves or cage and chain devices on fishing hooks reduced damage to catches by whales.
[Statement 3]: One study found that using devices like net sleeves or cage and chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
[Statement 4]: Other devices like ‘umbrella’ or ‘spider’ devices did not show a reduction in predation.
[Statement 5]: Streamer devices were only effective for a short period against dolphins.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found on the effects of catch protection devices used on longlines on reptile populations.
[Statement 7]: Modifying fishing pots has shown varied outcomes.
[Statement 8]: Two studies found that floating or semi-floating traps caught fewer unwanted invertebrates and fewer unwanted species compared to bottom traps.
[Statement 9]: The use of floating or semi-floating traps did not affect the commercial catch in two studies.
[Statement 10]: Modifying the design of traps had inconsistent effects on the amount of unwanted catch.
[Statement 11]: The effects of modifying trap designs on unwanted catch varied by trap design and area.
[Statement 12]: One study found that changing the bait in fishing pots did not alter the amount of unwanted invertebrates caught.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the outcomes of using catch protection devices on longlines compare to modifying fishing pots for reducing human-wildlife conflict?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the North Sea, Germany, found that using bubble curtains or screens during pile driving led to a smaller decrease in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km compared to sites without these measures.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of reducing hammer energy during pile driving.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations of delaying or ceasing operations if marine and freshwater mammals are detected within a specified zone.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What interventions are available to mitigate the impacts of underwater noise from construction activities like pile driving?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Following educational whale-watching tours or an educational exhibition, participants were more willing to change their behaviour to support marine conservation.
[Statement 2]: After educational whale-watching tours or an educational exhibition, participants were more willing to donate money to marine conservation.
[Statement 3]: After educational whale-watching tours or an educational exhibition, participants were more willing to cut their fishing nets to save entangled dolphins.
[Statement 4]: Three before-and-after studies were conducted in the North Atlantic Ocean, the Sundarbans mangroves, and the South Pacific Ocean.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented effects of education and community engagement programs on human behaviour towards marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The use of acoustic devices on fishing gear has been shown to reduce the entanglement of harbour porpoises, beaked whales, and other small cetaceans.
[Statement 2]: Studies have indicated that acoustic devices can lead to fewer encounters and interactions with nets for harbour porpoises.
[Statement 3]: Studies have indicated that acoustic devices can lead to fewer encounters and interactions with nets for common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 4]: Studies have indicated that acoustic devices can lead to fewer encounters and interactions with nets for other marine mammals.
[Statement 5]: The use of acoustic devices can lead to reduced activity and sightings of marine mammals in the surrounding areas.
[Statement 6]: The use of acoustic devices has been found to decrease damage to fish catches and fishing nets caused by seals.
[Statement 7]: The use of acoustic devices has been found to decrease damage to fish catches and fishing nets caused by common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 8]: Some studies have observed reduced activity of harbour porpoises around moorings equipped with acoustic devices.
[Statement 9]: The effectiveness of acoustic devices is not universally consistent.
[Statement 10]: Some studies found acoustic devices had no significant impact on the behaviour of certain dolphin and porpoise species.
[Statement 11]: The success of acoustic devices in preventing entanglement can vary between different species.
[Statement 12]: The success of acoustic devices in preventing entanglement can vary between different geographic locations.
[Statement 13]: One study found a reduction in harbour porpoise entanglements in one fishing area but not in another.
[Statement 14]: One study noted that a 'complete' set of acoustic devices reduced entanglements, while an 'incomplete' set did not.
[Statement 15]: There is a potential for habituation to acoustic devices.
[Statement 16]: One study on moorings indicated that the likelihood of harbour porpoises approaching an acoustic device increased over a period of 10–11 days.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the benefits and harms of using acoustic devices on fishing gear in coastal waters to protect porpoises?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using real-time automated tools at renewable energy sites to allow operations to be stopped or modified.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that assessed the impact of modifying the design of underwater turbines on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that assessed the impact of using acoustic devices at renewable energy sites on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 4]: It is not possible to determine if using real-time automated tools, modifying underwater turbines, or using acoustic devices are effective or have any harmful impacts.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of the evidence for actions designed to mitigate the risks of renewable energy infrastructure to marine and freshwater mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Installing steel rods or metal frames on pots reduced the entry or trapping of sea lions and seals.
[Statement 2]: Implementing wire grids, steel bars, and strengthened netting on traps reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 3]: A specific method of securing crab pot doors decreased interactions with bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 4]: Installing exclusion and escape devices on fishing gear for reptiles allowed loggerhead turtles to escape from trawl nets.
[Statement 5]: Trawl nets equipped with exclusion and escape devices caught fewer loggerhead turtles, sea turtles, and sea snakes compared to unmodified nets.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does the evidence for modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals compare with installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies, one in the Indian Ocean and one in the South Pacific Ocean, evaluated the effects of using baited lines instead of nets for shark control on marine mammals.
[Statement 2]: One site comparison study in the South Pacific Ocean found that using baited lines instead of nets increased the survival of entangled common and bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 3]: Two site comparison studies in the Indian Ocean and South Pacific Ocean found that baited lines used for shark control had fewer entanglements of dolphins, whales, and dugongs than nets.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using acoustic devices to deter marine and freshwater mammals from an area to reduce noise exposure has been found to reduce the activity and sightings of harbour porpoises.
[Statement 2]: Using acoustic devices to deter marine and freshwater mammals from an area to reduce noise exposure has caused minke whales to swim away from the acoustic devices.
[Statement 3]: In some studies, using acoustic devices at aquaculture systems reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
[Statement 4]: Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 5]: Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce the presence of common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using acoustic devices at renewable energy sites on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the Bay of Biscay, Spain, found that introducing secondary treatment of sewage wastewaters did not significantly change invertebrate community composition, richness, or diversity at an impacted site compared to unimpacted sites.
[Statement 2]: In a study in the Bay of Biscay, Spain, the total cover of invertebrates significantly increased at a sewage-impacted site at a depth of 8 meters after secondary wastewater treatment was introduced.
[Statement 3]: In a study in the Bay of Biscay, Spain, the total cover of invertebrates did not significantly increase at a sewage-impacted site at a depth of 3 meters after secondary wastewater treatment was introduced.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of limiting, ceasing, or prohibiting the dumping of untreated sewage on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of limiting the amount of storm wastewater overflow on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations.

_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the available strategies to reduce the negative impacts of aquaculture systems on marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of reducing the amount of antibiotics used in aquaculture systems on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that assessed the effects of introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of locating aquaculture systems in areas with fast currents.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of locating aquaculture systems in already impacted areas.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations of co-locating aquaculture systems with other activities and infrastructures.

parts.text:

[Statement 3]: When whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods avoided the vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 4]: When tour boats followed approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours, such as moving away, diving, or groups separating.
[Statement 5]: When boats approached a seal colony to 75m, more seals remained on shore than when boats approached to 25m.

[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing permits or licenses for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, the abundance of harbour seals increased over 7–30 years.
[Statement 2]: Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, the abundance of humpback whales increased over 7–30 years.
[Statement 3]: A review of the North Atlantic Ocean, North Pacific Ocean and the Southern Hemisphere found significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during the 7–21 years after legislation to prohibit hunting was introduced.
[Statement 4]: One study found that numbers of mature male sperm whales did not differ significantly before or 31 years after hunting was prohibited.

parts.text:

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A randomized, controlled study in the Puntledge River found that installing a ‘cork line’ barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 2]: A randomized, controlled study in the Puntledge River found that switching off artificial lights on a bridge did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies have evaluated the effectiveness of acoustic devices on fishing gear, vessels, and moorings.
[Statement 2]: Five of six controlled studies found that acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by dolphins and seals.
[Statement 3]: One study found that acoustic devices on fishing gear did not reduce damage to swordfish catches by sea lions.
[Statement 4]: Nine studies found that using acoustic devices on fishing nets or traps resulted in fewer entanglements or collisions of various marine mammals, including whales, porpoises, and dolphins.
[Statement 5]: Three studies found that acoustic devices led to fewer entanglements for some marine mammal species but not for others.
[Statement 6]: One study found that acoustic devices resulted in a reduction in entanglements in one fishing area but not in another.
[Statement 7]: Twelve of sixteen studies found that acoustic devices on nets caused porpoises, dolphins, and seals to avoid the fishing gear.
[Statement 8]: Four studies found that acoustic devices on nets had no significant effect on the behavior of porpoises, dolphins, and seals.
[Statement 9]: One controlled study found that common bottlenose dolphins avoided a boat more frequently when acoustic devices were deployed from the vessel.
[Statement 10]: Another study found that killer whales were recorded further from a fishing vessel using an acoustic device.
[Statement 11]: The effect of a fishing vessel's acoustic device on killer whales diminished over time.
[Statement 12]: A randomized, controlled study in the North Atlantic found that using two types of acoustic devices on vessels did not reduce predation of squid catches by Risso’s dolphins.
[Statement 13]: One randomized controlled study in the Puntledge River found that deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
[Statement 14]: Studies on moorings found mixed results on animal behavior, with some showing reduced activity of seals, porpoises and dolphins.
[Statement 15]: Other studies on moorings found acoustic devices had no effect on humpback whales.
[Statement 16]: One study noted that the probability of porpoises approaching an acoustic device on a mooring increased over a period of 10-11 days.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the comparative effectiveness of deploying acoustic devices on fishing gear, vessels, or moorings for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: 'Soft start’ procedures involve gradually increasing a noise level.
[Statement 2]: The use of ‘soft start’ procedures led to a greater proportion of cetaceans moving away from the noise source compared to when the noise was not present.
[Statement 3]: Short-finned whales that initially moved away from a vessel remained within 900m of the vessel.
[Statement 4]: Humpback whales slowed their speed but did not significantly alter their course in response to noise.
[Statement 5]: Acoustic devices can be used as a method to deter mammals.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic deterrent devices reduced the activity and sightings of harbour porpoises at distances of 1–18 km from wind farm construction sites.
[Statement 7]: Minke whales were observed to swim away from an acoustic device.
[Statement 8]: Minke whales were observed to increase their swimming speed in response to an acoustic device.
[Statement 9]: Minke whales were observed to swim more directly in response to an acoustic device.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

_gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies were found that evaluated the effects of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits.
[Statement 2]: A before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean discovered that implementing vessel speed limits during particular times in important habitats led to a decrease in the number of deaths of North Atlantic right whales resulting from collisions.
[Statement 3]: A separate before-and-after study conducted in the Indian River estuarine system revealed similar numbers of manatee fatalities before and after the implementation of vessel speed limits in 'zones'.
[Statement 4]: A reduction in manatee deaths was observed after speed limits were established and enforced throughout all areas.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that assessed the effects of diverting shipping routes.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that assessed the effects of modifying vessels to minimize the risk of physical harm to mammals.

[Statement 1]: A population of Mediterranean monk seals in the North Atlantic Ocean increased after the seals' island habitat was protected.
[Statement 2]: A study in the South Pacific Ocean found that the survival rate of Hector’s dolphins was higher after a coastal area was legally protected.
[Statement 3]: A bottlenose dolphin population in the North Sea was of a similar size before and after the dolphin population's range was protected.
[Statement 4]: A study in an Australian estuary reported a similar number of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings after legal protection was enacted.
[Statement 5]: The number of human-caused strandings of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins decreased in an Australian estuary after legal protection was enacted.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of establishing a network of legally protected areas for marine and freshwater mammal species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented population-level outcomes of legally protecting marine mammals and their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: One study out of twelve on hand-rearing orphaned or abandoned marine and freshwater mammals found that most captive-reared Antillean manatees released into the wild reproduced.
[Statement 2]: Several studies found that released animals survived post-release.
[Statement 3]: One study showed survival rates for captive-reared Pacific harbour seal pups were similar to wild pups.
[Statement 4]: Other studies reported that some captive-reared animals died before or after release.
[Statement 5]: Some captive-reared animals had to be returned to captivity.
[Statement 6]: Some captive-reared animals only survived with supplemental feeding.
[Statement 7]: Some animals died while still in captivity.
[Statement 8]: In a study on releasing captive-bred animals, a low number of Antillean and Florida manatees survived for at least a year in the wild.
[Statement 9]: Studies on breeding in captivity have shown successful births and survival of young for Indo-Pacific dolphins and common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 10]: Most captive-born Amazon river dolphins, narrow-ridged finless porpoises, and Irrawaddy dolphins did not survive in captivity.
[Statement 11]: A study on a semi-captive population of Yangtze finless porpoises found low genetic diversity.
[Statement 12]: Two controlled studies found that captive-reared and released seal and sea lion pups had similar diving behavior to wild pups.
[Statement 13]: Another study found captive-reared seal pups traveled greater distances from the release site than wild pups.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented benefits and negative outcomes associated with captive rearing and rehabilitation of marine mammals?
